questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to the gynecology clinic seeking long-term contraception. She has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea.She has no significant medical history and is not currently taking any medications. After discussing various options, she is interested in intrauterine devices.Which of the following is the most appropriate intrauterine device (IUCD) for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B) Levonorgestrel-releasing IUCD (Mirena)

Explanation:

The Levonorgestrel-releasing IUCD (Mirena) provides effective long-term contraception as it is every 5 years and also reduces menstrual bleeding as levonorgestrel hormone thins the endometrial lining, leading to lighter periods and reduced menstrual pain.

Levonorgestrel containing IUCD

 

A)Copper T 380A is effective long-term as it should be replaced every 10 years but, it may worsen the symptoms in women due to increased menstrual bleeding and cramping.

C)The Multiload 375 is a copper-containing IUCD, it should be replaced every 5 years and it does not address heavy menstrual bleeding or dysmenorrhea and may exacerbate these conditions.

 

D)Progestasert is a hormone-releasing IUCD that contains progesterone, it needs to be replaced annually,it is less effective at reducing heavy menstrual bleeding compared to Mirena.

Type of IUCD

Examples

Composition

MOA

Duration

Advantages

First Generation

Lippes loop

Non medicated made of polyethylene or other polymers
  • Leads to foreign body reaction producing sterile inflammatory responses

10 years
  • Long duration
  • double "S" shape closely fit the contours of the uterine cavity, reducing the chance of expulsion

Second Generation

 

(Copper IUCDs)

Copper T 380

Copper wire wrapped around the IUCD
  • Releases copper ions which are spermicidal
  • Impairs sperm motility and viability
  • Interfere with the capacitation of sperm

10-12 years
  • Long duration
  • No hormones involved
  • Suitable for those who cannot use hormonal contraception

Third Generation

 

(Hormonal IUCDs)
  • Mirena
  • Progestasert

Levonorgestrel
  • Releases levonorgestrel (progestin)
  • Thickens cervical mucus
  • Alters endometrial lining
  • May suppress ovulation in some women

5-7 years
  • Lighter menstrual periods
  • Reduced menstrual cramps
  • Protection against endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)?

choices.text: If a single OCP pill is missed, a new pack must be started immediately.
OCPs increase the risk of ovarian and endometrial cancers.
Missing three consecutive OCP pills during the first week necessitates using an additional contraceptive method for at least 7 days.
OCPs can be taken at any time of day without impacting their effectiveness.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Missing three consecutive OCP pills during the first week necessitates using an additional contraceptive method for at least 7 days.

Explanation:

Missing three consecutive OCP pills during the first week necessitates using an additional contraceptive method for at least 7 days is correct.

If three combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are missed, it is advised to take one pill the next day and then continue the pack as scheduled. Using a backup form of contraception, such as a condom, is recommended for the next seven days.

(Option A) If a single OCP pill is missed, a new pack must be started immediately is incorrect. If a woman forgets to take one OCP pill (up to 24 hours late), she should take the missed pill immediately and continue the rest of the pack as scheduled.

(Option B) OCPs increase the risk of ovarian and endometrial cancers is incorrect. The combined oral contraceptives (OCPs) have a protective effect against these cancers. 


(Option D) OCPs can be taken at any time of day without impacting their effectiveness is incorrect. OCPs can be taken at any time of day, but taking the pill at a particular time simultaneously every day is recommended for maximum effectiveness.

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman suffering from migraine without aura for the past 2 years wants to start on OCPs. She is also a known smoker for the past 12 years. Which adverse effect is the highest risk and likely to contraindicate its use?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) - It is a major complication of OCP use and increases the risk of VTE three to fivefold, especially in individuals with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or who smoke.

B) Headache- It is a minor complication of OCP use.

C) Hypertension- OCPs can potentially increase blood pressure, but this is generally a manageable side effect with regular monitoring and lifestyle adjustments. The risk is significant, also a major complication but not as immediately dangerous as VTE in a high-risk individual.

D) Dysmenorrhea- OCPs often help alleviate rather than the cause. It is not an adverse effect.

Minor Complications:

  • Nausea, Vomiting, Headache (Option B)
  • Mastalgia
  • Weight Gain
  • Chloasma and Acne
  • Menstrual Abnormalities:
    • Breakthrough Bleeding
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Menorrhagia
    • Amenorrhea
  • Libido
  • Leukorrhea

Major Complications:

  • Depression
  • Hypertension (Option C)
  • Vascular Complications:
    • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) (Option A)
    • Arterial Thrombosis
  • Cholestatic Jaundice
  • Neoplasia:
    • The relationship between OCPs and cervical carcinoma is unclear, but regular screening is recommended for users.
  • Death: The risk of death for OCP users is very low.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an action of the combined oral contraceptive pill?

choices.text: Suppression of ovulation through inhibition of pituitary hormones.
Thickening of cervical mucus to block sperm entry.
Induction of atrophic changes in the endometrium to prevent implantation.
Kills the sperm in the cervix.

questions.solution:
Correction  Option D The OCPs do not have spermicidal action.

(Option A) The combined oral contraceptive pill suppresses ovulation by inhibiting pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH.

(Option B) The progestogen in the pill makes the cervical mucus thick and tenacious, preventing sperm from penetrating.

(Option C) The progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium, making it unsuitable for implantation.

The combined OCPs also increase tubal motility, leading to the fertilized egg reaching the uterus before the endometrium is ready for implantation.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to your clinic for contraception advice. She has a past h/o deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago. What is this patient's Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) category for combined oral contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

B) The correct answer is MEC 4. According to the WHO MEC Criteria for Contraceptive Use, women with h/o DVT should not use combined hormonal contraceptives (CHCs) due to the increased risk of recurrent thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, stroke, and MI which represent high health risks.

MEC Categories for Contraceptive Eligibility

MEC 1

A condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method. (C)

MEC 2

A condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks. (D)

MEC 3

A condition where the theoretical or proven risks usually outweigh the advantages of using the method. (A)

MEC 4

A condition that represents an unacceptable health risk if the contraceptive method is used.

questions.text: A woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents with excessive vomiting and slight bleeding from the vagina. On USG snow storm appearance is seen in the uterus. Molar evacuation is performed and she is asked to avoid pregnancy for 6 months. She can use all of the following contraceptive devices except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) IUCD 

 

Explanation:

  • IUCD is contraindicated after molar evacuation until β-hCG levels are undetectable because of the risk of uterine perforation if an invasive mole is present.
  • Also, the uterus is soft after suction and evacuation, so IUCD insertion may cause perforation
  • Pregnancy is avoided for at least 6 months after molar evacuation because β-hCG levels from pregnancy and trophoblastic disease will be hard to differentiate.

 

Other special situations and related contraceptive methods:

Situation

Contraceptives used

Contraceptives avoided

Molar Pregnancy
  • OCP (Contraceptive of choice)
  • POP
  • DMPA
  • Condom

IUCD (Risk of uterine perforation)

Heart disease

IUCD
  • OCP
  • POP

(Both can cause water retention)

Uncontrolled Diabetes

Barriers with spermicidal agents

OCP (Both estrogen and sugar are metabolized by liver, increased sugar levels can interfere with contraception)

Newly married couple

OCP

  

Postnatal/lactation
  • POP (till 6 wks)
  • IUCD (after 6 wks)

OCP (Estrogen component can cause lactational failure)

OCPs (Option A) are contraceptives of choice after molar evacuation. They inhibit ovulation, and make cervical mucus thick.

POPs (Option C) also cause anovulation and are contraceptive of choice in lactating females.

Condom (Option D) is a barrier method of contraception and is safe to use after molar evacuation.

questions.text: Identify the following contraceptive device:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Diaphragm

Explanation:

Diaphragm is an intravaginal device made of latex.

  • It alone can't prevent the ascent of sperm completely so it is used with a spermicidal agent (Nonoxynol 9).
  • Failure rate: 16 per hundred women years
  • The device is introduced up to 3 hours before intercourse and is to be kept for at least 8 hours after the last coital act.

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Cheap
  • Can be used repeatedly for a long time
  • Reduces PID/STIs to some extent
  • Risk of vaginal irritation, abrasion and urinary tract infection are there
  • Requires help of a doctor or paramedical person to measure the size required
  • Not suitable in case of uterine prolapse.

 

Option A) Femidom is a female condom.

  • It is made of polyurethane which lines the vagina and external genitalia.
  • Failure rate is 5-21/HWY.
  • The inner smaller ring (closed end) is inserted at the apex of vagina and the outer ring is outside.
  • It protects against PID/STD's

 

Option C) Today sponge is a barrier method of contraception kept in the vagina, and uses Nonoxynol 9 as a spermicidal agent.

  • Mechanism:
    • Releases spermicide during coitus, which disrupts sperm cell membrane.
    • Absorbs ejaculate.
    • Blocks the entrance to the cervical canal.
  • It has to be kept for 6 hours after intercourse for effective action.
  • Side effects are allergic reaction and vaginal dryness.
  • Failure rate: 9-16 per hundred woman years

Option D) Condom (Male condom) is made of polyurethane or latex. Failure rate is 15/HWY. In India brand name Nirodh is distributed free of cost.

 

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Cost effective.
  • No side effects.
  • Easy to carry, simple to use and disposable
  • Protection against PID/STIs.
  • Reduces the incidence of tubal infertility and ectopic pregnancy.
  • May accidentally break or slip off during coitus
  • Inadequate sexual pleasure
  • Allergic reaction (latex)

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct statement about injectable progesterone?

DMPA- Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate

NET-EN- norethisterone enanthate

choices.text: DMPA is administered i.m. every 2 months.
NET-EN is administered i.m. every 3 months.
They can be safely used in lactating women. .
They are associated with an increased risk of thromboembolism compared to cOCPs.

questions.solution:
Answer: C)They can be safely used in lactating women.

 

Explanation:

Injectable progesterone is safe in lactating women. It is safe because it does not change milk composition.

Mechanism of action of Injectable progesterone:

  • Inhibition of ovulation
  • Makes cervical mucus thick and viscid preventing sperm penetration
  • Prevents implantation.

 

Option A) DMPA is administered i.m. every 2 months is incorrect because it is given in a dose of 150 mg every 3 months. It comes under the brand name Antara.

  • DMPA reduces the risk of iron deficiency anemia, sickle cell problems, and endometriosis.
  • There is delayed return of fertility (6-12 months)
  • Side effect: Reduced bone mineral density, depression, weight gain, and headache.

Option B) NET-EN is administered i.m. every 3 months is incorrect because it is given in a dose of 200mg every 2 months.


Option D) They are associated with an increased risk of thromboembolism compared to COCPs is incorrect. Since these are estrogen free, the risk of thromboembolism is minimal.

questions.text: Which of the following does not use estrogen + progesterone (E+P) combination as a method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Today sponge

Explanation:

  • Today sponge is a barrier method of contraception kept in vagina, and uses Nonoxynol 9 as a spermicidal agent.
  • Mechanism:
    • Releases spermicide during coitus, which disrupts sperm cell membrane.
    • Absorbs ejaculate.
    • Blocks the entrance to the cervical canal.
  • It has to be kept for 6 hours after intercourse for effective action.
  • Side effects are allergic reaction and vaginal dryness.

Options A and B) NUVA ring and EVRA patch both use E+P combination. The differences are given below:

 
  1. NUVA ring
  1. EVRA patch

Contents

E- Ethinyl estradiol

P- Etonogestrel

E- Ethinyl estradiol

P- Norelgestromin

Release rates

E- 15 mcg/day

P- 120 mcg/day

E- 20 mcg/ day

P- 150 mcg/day

Method of use

1 ring kept in vagina

for 3 weeks

followed by 1 week off

1 patch/ week

for 3 weeks ( total 3 patches)

followed by 1 week off

Images



 

 

Option D) COCPs- These use E+P combination.

Mechanism:

  • Main- Inhibits ovulation due to negative feedback of progesterone on LH.
  • Inhibits folliculogenesis due to negative feedback of estrogen on FSH.
  • Progesterone thickens cervical mucus and prevents sperm penetration.
  • Interferes with tubal motility.

questions.text:
Match the type of contraceptive implant with its description: 


	
		
			
			Contraceptive Implant
			
			
			Description
			
		
		
			
			a. Implanon
			
			
			i. Consists of a single rod radio-opaque implant with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years.
			
		
		
			
			b. Nexplanon
			
			
			ii. Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years.
			
		
		
			
			c. Jadelle
			
			
			iii. Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years.
			
		
		
			
			d. Norplant
			
			
			iv. Consists of six small, flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of the upper arm.
questions.solution:
Answer: A) a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv

Explanation:

Implanon

Nexplanon

Jadelle

Norplant

Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years.

Consists of a single rod implant with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years. It is radio-opaque (it contains barium), so can be located on X-ray if necessary.

 

Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years.

 





 

Consists of six small,flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of upper arm.
  • Fewer adverse effects reported
  • Similar to Implanon
  • Fewer adverse effects compared to Norplant
  • Higher incidence of irregular bleeding
  • Difficulty due to multiple rods
  • Straightforward insertion and removal
  • Preloaded applicator for easier insertion and removal
  • Easier insertion and removal compared to Norplant
  • Complicated insertion and removal due to multiple rods

questions.text: Which compound is the active ingredient in Saheli tablets, a non-hormonal oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Centrochroman

Explanation:
Centrochroman:

  • Active ingredient in Saheli tablets.
  • It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as a non-hormonal contraceptive by affecting estrogen receptors in the body.
  • It prevents the implantation of the fertilized ovum.
  • It does not inhibit ovulation.
  • Dosage: Take 30mg (oral) twice a week for the first 3 months then after once a week.

 

Levonorgestrel (Option A) is a synthetic progestin used in many hormonal contraceptives, including some emergency contraceptive pills and intrauterine devices (IUDs).

Drospirenone (Option B) is a synthetic progestin used in combination with estrogen in some birth control pills to prevent pregnancy.

Desogestrel (Option C) is another synthetic progestin used in various hormonal contraceptives, including birth control pills and contraceptive implants.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mini-pill (progestin-only pill, POP) is true regarding its use in lactating women?

choices.text: Early return of fertility once discontinued
It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women
It is associated with a higher risk of blood clots compared to combined oral contraceptives

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women.

 

Explanation:

  • Progestin-only pills (POP) are generally preferred for breastfeeding women because they do not significantly affect milk production. In contrast, estrogen-containing contraceptives can sometimes decrease milk supply.
  • It has to be taken at the same time daily from the first day of the cycle.

Disadvantages of POP:

  • The mini-pill (POP) causes delayed return of fertility after Discontinuation (Option A ruled out)
  • POP causes Bone loss (Option C ruled out)

 

Progestin only pills(POP)

Dose

Window Period

Minipill [Levonorgestrel]

35 mcg

3hrs

Cerazette [Desogestrel]

75 mcg

12hrs

 

Option D: Progestin-only pills (POP) are associated with a lower risk of blood clots compared to combined oral contraceptives that contain estrogen. Therefore, they are often preferred for women at higher risk of clotting disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents a type of oral contraceptive formulation used for birth control?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Combination Pill

Explanation:

Combination Pill contains both estrogen and progestin hormones. They are taken daily to prevent pregnancy by suppressing ovulation, thickening cervical mucus, and altering the endometrial lining.

1. Monophasic OCPs:

  • Contains a fixed dose of both estrogen and progestin throughout the entire pill pack.
  • Each active pill in the pack has the same hormone levels.
  • Helps in reducing side effects and regulating menstrual cycles more predictably.

2. Multiphasic OCPs:

  • contains varying levels of estrogen and progestin hormones throughout the pill pack.
  • It mimics the natural hormonal fluctuations of a woman's menstrual cycle more closely than monophasic pills.
  • It is of two types (Biphasic and Triphasic)

Biphasic pills:

  • Composition: Biphasic pills contain a fixed dose of estrogen throughout the entire cycle but vary the dose of progestin in two phases.
  • Phases: These pills are designed to be taken in two distinct phases during the menstrual cycle:
    • First phase: In the first half of the cycle (e.g., 1-14 days), the progestin component is low
    • Second phase: In the second half of the cycle (e.g., 15-28 days), where the progestin component is increased.

Triphasic pills:

  • Composition: Triphasic pills contain varying doses of both estrogen and progestin in three phases throughout the menstrual cycle.
  • Phases: These pills are typically packaged in a 28-day pill pack, with the hormones divided into three distinct phases:
    • First phase: low doses of both hormones to simulate the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
    • Second phase: Moderate doses of hormones to mimic the mid-cycle hormonal surge.
    • Third phase: High doses of progestin (and sometimes estrogen) to simulate the luteal phase and prepare for menstruation.

Regimen:

1. 21-Day Pack (Traditional Pack):

  • Take one pill every day for 21 days (hormone pills)
  • After finishing the 21 pills, do not take any pills for 7 days
  • Start a new pack on the 8th day, regardless of whether bleeding has stopped.

2. 28-Day Pack (Extended Cycle Pack):

 

  • Take one active pill containing hormones every day for 28 days.
  • Some packs contain 21 active pills and 7 inactive (ferrous fumarate) pills.
  • Other packs contain 24 active pills and 4 inactive pills.
  • The inactive pills are taken during the last week of the cycle.
  • Withdrawal bleeding (similar to a period) typically occurs during the week of inactive pills.

DMPA (Option B), Depo Medroxy Progesterone Acetate is a injectable progesterone given as 150 mg IM every 3 months.

Implanon (Option C), is a progesterone (etonorgestral) implant, a small rod inserted under the skin of the arm that releases progestin to prevent pregnancy.

Diaphragm (Option D) is a barrier method of contraception that is inserted into the vagina before sex to block sperm from reaching the uterus.

questions.text: Which of these conditions or characteristics would make drospirenone-containing combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) potentially inappropriate for use?
questions.solution:
Drospirenone, a progestin in some combined oral contraceptives (COCs), mimics progesterone but has unique properties.

  • Drospirenone may elevate blood potassium levels (hyperkalemia), making it inappropriate for individuals with renal compromise and adrenal insufficiency. (Option B)
  • It resembles spironolactone structurally.
  • Drospirenone blocks androgen effects, helping conditions like acne and hirsutism. (Option A)
  • It acts as an anti-mineralocorticoid, reducing water retention, thus not leading to weight gain.
  • Monitoring potassium is advised if used with drugs that raise potassium levels like NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, Angiotensin II antagonists, Heparin, Aldosterone antagonists, and Potassium-sparing diuretics. (Option D)
  • COCs with drospirenone can help manage Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). (Option C)
  • There's a slightly higher VTE (venous thromboembolism) risk compared to other COCs, but the benefits generally outweigh the risks.
  • Drospirenone-only pills inhibit ovulation with a 12-hour missed-pill window.

questions.text: Which of the following women should seek alternative contraception methods due to absolute contraindications for combined oral contraceptive pills?

choices.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines without aura
A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer
A 25-year-old woman with well-managed type1 diabetes

questions.solution:
C) A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer

  • A history of breast cancer is an absolute contraindication for combined oral contraceptive pills.
  • Estrogen exposure from hormonal contraceptives could potentially promote the growth of hormone-sensitive breast cancer cells.

 

A) A 28-year-old woman with controlled hypothyroidism

  • Controlled hypothyroidism does not significantly increase the risk associated with estrogen-containing contraceptives and is not considered an absolute contraindication for combined oral contraceptive pills.

 

B) A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines without aura:

  • Migraines without aura are generally not a contraindication for combined oral contraceptive pills.
  • Migraines with aura are considered a contraindication due to the increased risk of stroke.

 

D) A 25-year-old woman with well-managed type 1 diabetes

  • Well-managed type 1 diabetes is not an absolute contraindication for combined oral contraceptive pills.
  • It’s essential to monitor blood sugar levels closely as contraceptives can affect glucose metabolism.


 

Absolute Contraindications of Combined Oral Contraceptives Pills (COCs)

Condition

Remarks

Pregnancy
  • COCs are strictly prohibited during pregnancy.

Circulatory Diseases (Past or Present)
  • Women who have a history of arterial or venous thrombosis, severe hypertension, stroke, or heart disease (valvular or ischemic) should avoid combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs).
  • The estrogen component in COCs can raise the risk of deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • This is because estrogen stimulates the liver to produce fibrinogen and clotting factors, which can contribute to clot formation.

Liver Diseases
  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) should not be used by women with active liver disease, jaundice, liver adenoma, or liver carcinoma.
  • The estrogen in COCs can increase the synthesis of hepatic angiotensinogen, which may contribute to hypertension.

Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding
  • COC use is not recommended for women with undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding.

Breast Cancer (Current or Past)
  • Women with known or suspected breast cancer should not use COCs.

Major Surgery or Prolonged Immobilisation
  • COCs are contraindicated in women who have recently undergone major surgery or experienced prolonged immobilization due to the increased risk of postoperative VTE.

Estrogen-Dependent Neoplasms
  • Women with known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasms should avoid using COCs.

Smoking and Age
  • COCs are not recommended for women older than 35 who smoke.

Diabetes with Vascular Complications
  • Women with diabetes and vascular complications should not use COCs.

Migraines with Focal Neurologic Symptoms
  • COCs should be avoided by women experiencing migraines with focal neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for insertion of an Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD)?
questions.solution:
Correct option: a)  Sexually transmitted infections within 6months.

Explanation:

A)Sexually transmitted infections in the present or within 3months are contraindicated for insertion of IUCD.

B)Pelvic Inflammatory Disease contraindicated in insertion of IUCD as it can exacerbate the infection and spreading bacteria into further reproductive tracts.

C)Trophoblastic disease is contraindicated in inserting IUCD because there is risk of uterine perforation due to change in uterine tissue fragility following the use of chemotherapy and also it is associated with abnormal vascularization and blood flow in the uterus so inserting IUCD can result in heavy bleeding.

D)Wilson’s disease is contraindicated in insertion of Cu-T intrauterine contraceptive as this disease primarily affects copper metabolism causing copper to build up in liver, brain and other organs.

questions.text: Which of the following natural contraception methods requires the combined use of tracking basal body temperature, monitoring cervical mucus, and recording menstrual cycle lengths to identify the fertile window?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Rhythm method

Explanation:

A) Standard Days Method - This method involves avoiding unprotected intercourse on days 8-19 of the menstrual cycle for women with cycles that are 26-32 days long.

B) Rhythm method - This method combines tracking basal body temperature(temperature rhythm), monitoring changes in cervical mucus(mucus rhythm) and recording menstrual cycle lengths(calendar rhythm) to accurately determine the fertile window.

C) TwoDay Method - This method involves checking for cervical secretions each day. If secretions are present today or were present yesterday, the woman is considered fertile.

D) Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) - This method relies on exclusive breastfeeding to delay the return of fertility postpartum, effective only within the first six months after childbirth if menstruation has not resumed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female G2P1 presents to the clinic at 7 weeks gestation by LMP. She reports using an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for contraception. On examination, the IUCD strings are not visualized on the speculum exam. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pelvic ultrasound

Explanation:

 

The next step in management is to determine the location of the pregnancy to rule out ectopic pregnancy and the location of IUCD. This can be best accomplished with a pelvic ultrasound.

 

Management of IUCD in Pregnancy

Confirm Pregnancy

  • Perform a urine pregnancy test.
  • Confirm with an ultrasound to assess gestational age and rule out ectopic pregnancy.

Assess IUCD Position

  • Use ultrasound (transvaginal or abdominal) to check IUCD placement: correctly positioned, partially expelled, or displaced.

IUCD String Visibility

Visible Strings:

Gently remove the IUCD by pulling on the strings after explaining the possible risks to the mother.

No Strings Visible

Continue the pregnancy with monitoring.

Risks of Pregnancy with IUCD

  • Increased risk of miscarriage
  • Preterm birth
  • Infection (intra-amniotic infection or septic abortion)
  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)

Combined oral contraceptive pills(Option A) are not appropriate in this scenario as the patient is already pregnant. They would not address the issue of the missing IUCD strings or the management of the pregnancy with an IUCD in situ.

Hysterosalpingogram(Option C) is a radiologic procedure that is used to evaluate the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity in non-pregnant females for infertility workup.

Reassurance(Option D) is a component of patient care, observation without further investigation could result in missed opportunities for intervention and is not the MOST appropriate next step in this case.

Note: If an IUD is present with a desired pregnancy, removal is recommended to minimize pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, preterm labor, and infection. However, if removal is not feasible or the pregnancy is undesired, Pregnancy termination with manual vacuum aspiration should be done.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, lower abdominal pain, and abnormal vaginal discharge for the past week. She had an IUCD inserted two months ago. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and cervical motion tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: c) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)

Explanation:

  • PID is a known complication of IUCD use, within the first few months after insertion.
  • It presents with symptoms like fever, lower abdominal pain, abnormal vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness, which match the patient's presentation.
  • Infections with gonorrhea, chlamydia and rarely with actinomyces are seen.
  • Mostly a result of aseptic technique of insertion or pre-existing infection rather than due to IUCD itself

 

A) IUCD-associated heavy menstrual bleeding: This condition is characterized by increased menstrual flow and cramping, not with fever, lower abdominal pain, or abnormal vaginal discharge. Menstrual loss is much less with the use of third-generation IUDs

 

B) Ectopic pregnancy: Present with abdominal pain and tenderness, but it often includes missed periods and may not present with fever or significant vaginal discharge.

Incidence of pregnancy is less for women with IUCD compared to normal women

Therefore Incidence of ectopic pregnancy is also less in IUCD users

But if a woman with IUCD is pregnant—--> Rule out ectopic pregnancy

D) IUCD perforation: Typically causes severe abdominal pain soon after insertion and may require surgical intervention. The presence of fever and discharge is more indicative of an infection than a mechanical injury.Ultrasonography can detect the IUD in the abdominal cavity and is better than radiography.

SIDE EFFECTS OF IUCD

IMMEDIATE

REMOTE
  • Cramp-like pain
  • Abnormal menstrual bleeding(most common)
  • Syncopal attack
  • Pain (2nd most common)
  • Partial or complete perforation
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Spontaneous expulsion
  • Perforation of the uterus

Pain, abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) & PID are the main factors related to its discontinuation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman inquiring about long-acting contraception options is considering an IUCD. What is the primary mechanism of action of the instrument in the image?
questions.solution:
IUCDs primarily prevent fertilization by altering the uterine environment, making it unfavorable for sperm survival and reducing the likelihood of sperm reaching the egg for fertilization.

A) Inhibition of sperm motility:

This is not the primary mechanism of action of IUCDs. While IUCDs can affect sperm movement within the uterus, their main mechanism of action does not rely on inhibiting sperm motility directly.

C) Thickening of cervical mucus:

This mechanism is associated with hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills or hormonal IUCDs (like the hormonal IUD). It does not apply to non-hormonal copper IUCDs, which do not affect cervical mucus.

D) Inhibition of ovulation:

This is the mechanism of action for hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills or hormonal IUCDs, but it does not apply to non-hormonal copper IUCDs.

Prevention of Implantation: IUCDs modify the endometrial lining, making it less conducive to implantation, though this is a secondary mechanism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old newly married woman wants effective contraception with a minimum failure rate. Which contraceptive method would be the most suitable for her considering both efficacy and ease of use?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

Correct Answer - Option A- Implants

Implants: The 3-year implant has one of the lowest failure rates at 0.05%, indicating high effectiveness. This method is suitable for a newly married woman who desires reliable contraception without daily adherence. The implant also offers long-term protection (up to 3 years) with minimal user intervention after insertion, making it convenient.

Option B) Oral Pills: While pills are commonly used and also effective with perfect use 0.3% failure rate, their typical use failure rate is higher at 8%. They require daily administration and the potential for missed doses affecting efficacy, implants are preferred over pills.

Option C) Condoms: They have a typical use failure rate of 15%, making them less effective compared to the implant. Condoms are suitable for dual protection (against pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections) but may not provide the desired level of contraceptive reliability on their own.

Option D) IUD: Both the levonorgestrel IUD-0.2% and copper T IUD device- 0.8% have low failure rates, but more than the implant. However, some disadvantages include menstrual irregularities, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain due to which implants are preferred.

The Pearl Index is an indicator of Couple protection practices in the community. It is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 women years of exposure. It is the percentage of eligible couples protected against childbirth by family planning.

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman visits her gynecologist seeking advice on starting oral OCP. She prefers a low-dose option with both progestogen and estrogen components. What is the correct dose of the prescribed OCP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Combined OCP contains a combination of Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinyl estradiol in doses of 20-30 micrograms.
  • Mala D and Mala N contain the same composition and Mala N is available free of cost in Family Planning Clinics in India.
  • The tablets should be taken beginning on the first day of the menstrual cycle and continued for 21 days. A new cycle of tablets should start 7 days after finishing the previous one. It is recommended to take the tablet at the same time each day, ideally after a meal.
  • Combined OCPs, taken as a split dose, one dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG, followed by a second dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG 12 hours later. (Yuzpe method)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Copper T 380A intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD)?

choices.text: It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.
It releases levonorgestrel to suppress ovulation and thin the endometrium.
It is a first-generation IUCD made of inert plastic without any medication.
It is effective for only 5 years and mainly used for women with heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.solution:
Correct option: A) It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.

Explanation:

Copper T 380A is a second-generation (copper-containing) IUCD. It works by releasing copper ions, which are spermicidal, impairing sperm motility, viability, and capacitation. It is effective for 10-12 years and does not contain hormones.

Copper T 380A

 

Type of IUCD

Examples

Composition

MOA

Duration

Advantages

First Generation (Option C)

Lippes loop

Non medicated made of polyethylene or other polymers
  • Leads to foreign body reaction producing sterile inflammatory responses

10 years
  • Long duration
  • double "S" shape closely fit the contours of the uterine cavity, reducing the chance of expulsion

Second Generation (Copper IUCDs)

Copper T 380

Copper wire wrapped around the IUCD
  • Releases copper ions which are spermicidal
  • Impairs sperm motility and viability
  • Interfere with the capacitation of sperm

10-12 years (Option D)
  • Long duration
  • No hormones involved
  • Suitable for those who cannot use hormonal contraception

Third Generation (Hormonal IUCDs) (Option B)
  • Mirena
  • Progestasert

Levonorgestrel
  • Releases levonorgestrel (progestin)
  • Thickens cervical mucus
  • Alters endometrial lining
  • May suppress ovulation in some women

5-7 years
  • Lighter menstrual periods
  • Reduced menstrual cramps
  • Protection against endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Works by releasing hormones to prevent pregnancy (Option B): It works by releasing copper ions, which create an inflammatory reaction in the uterus that is toxic to sperm and ova, also reduces sperm motility, thereby preventing fertilization

 

Increases the absolute risk of ectopic pregnancy (Option D): IUCDs slightly increase the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy if a pregnancy occurs, the Copper T 380A is very effective at preventing pregnancy overall. The absolute risk of ectopic pregnancy is lower in women using IUCDs compared to those not using contraception at all.
